challenges.  See Assoc. Compl. ¶¶ 89–99.  And Count 
III, which alleges arbitrary and capricious action, does not even list the four specific actions at 
all.  See id. ¶¶ 100–02.  Instead, it lodges a general allegation that the Department acted 
“arbitrarily and capricious by attempting to render an executive agency incapable of carrying 
out [its] statutory functions.”  Id. ¶ 102. 
In its quest to revivify the Institute, the Association seeks a remedy larger than the sum of 
the individual injuries it alleges.  The overall goal is not incremental correction by fixing specific 
erroneous decisions, but a grand decree blocking all actions that risk “render[ing] an executive 
agency incapable of carrying out [its] statutory functions.”  Id. To that end, the Association 
wants a sweeping order that “reinstate[s
